title: builder whose 150 home plans were refused says 550 folk overwhelmingly from dundee are interested
story: A housebuilder has hit out at councillors in Dundee who turned down its plan to build  homes earlier this year, describing their decision as “baffling”.Kirkwood Homes is appealing against a decision by Dundee’s planning committee to reject its proposal for a new housing development at Linlathen, north of Broughty Ferry in June.Colin Crombie, managing director at Kirkwood Homes, told the Tele he found it hard to understand councillors’ thinking, given that planning officers had recommended the plans be approved.He said: “We had worked closely and very well with Dundee City Council’s planning officers to ensure that this £ million development met their own policies, guidance and aspirations.“Once again, we were left baffled by the decision of councillors to ignore the advice of their officers, as well as the  notes of interest that came overwhelmingly from the Dundee area – interest that demonstrated a clear desire and need for new housing of this type in and around Broughty Ferry.”He said that, because of the support of planning officials and locals the firm “simply had no choice” but to appeal.The Scottish Government is likely to make a decision on the appeal before the end of the year.

title: can roarie be dundees deacon of hope
story: Former Arsenal kid Roarie Deacon’scoincided with Dundee’s first league victory of the season – could he be the piece that’s been missing from their Premiership jigsaw The -year-old, who signed from English National League side Sutton United last summer, has missed the entire start of the season after having ankle surgery.Picking up the injury in the final game of last season, the enigmatic attacker ed for the final six minutes of the club’s first league win of the season – at the seventh time of the asking – at Hamilton and, in the process, set up the second goal.And hiswas hailed by manager Neil McCann.He said: “Roarie Deacon I am really pleased about getting back in because we have suffered some real injury problems of late.“He hadn’t featured at all, he’d only had  minutes of football all season before Saturday but I knew putting him on he could secure the ball because he is so strong.“You can’t get close to Roarie and he turned the boy beautully, then he had the composure.“I have to commend the other boys as well because they were still trying to get into the box at that stage to get the killer goal.”Deacon himself was delighted to be back in action after his y spell out.A process that was extended after an older injury reared its head once more.His debut season was also curtailed by injury with a troublesome thigh problem picked up in December at Hearts keeping him out of action for a big chunk of the middle of the campaign.And, on histo training this season, he hurt the same thigh once more.Deacon said: “I had ankle surgery the first week into pre-season.“I twisted it and damaged ankle ligaments in the game against Partick and through the summer it didn’t heal itself.“The surgeon didn’t want to operate initially but it didn’t heal itself so we made the decision to go under the kne to sort it out.“I was supposed to be back a little earlier than this but on the first session back I re-injured my thigh, a problem I had last season, so I needed a bit of intense rehabilitation on that to get back.“Now, though, I am ready to go and I’m fit.”With goals being a real issue for the side – just four scored in their seven league games and half of them against Accies at the weekend – Deacon’sis a timely boost for the Dark Blues.In fact, he’s only played around six minutes this season but has already had a hand in a quarter of their league goals.Coming into the side struggling for goals and points, though, hasn’t ruffled Deacon in any way.And Dundee fans will be hoping his direct running and ability to go past people is the key that unlocks defences with tough matches against Kilmarnock on Saturday and then Livingston, Hearts and Celtic in the next month.The former Sutton man admits he’s surprised the Dark Blues find themselves bottom of the table as he s to fitness and has backed them to get up the table,they keep doing what they’ve been doing.He added: “I am very surprised, everyone is surprised.“No way we thought we would come in, do well in pre-season, and then come in and after six games not have a point on the board.“However, after Hamilton everyone is positive, you can’t not be because the way we’ve been playing it’s not like we’ve not created chances or played well despite not getting points.“Everyone is buzzing about in training, raring to go and wanting to do well for Dundee.”

title: closed dundee gp practice closes its doors for good
story: A Dundee GP practice has closed its doors to patients for the final time.Fintry Mill Medical Centre shut for good at pm on Friday after efforts to recruit more GPs failed.All services will be transferred to Arthurstone Medical Centre on Arthurstone Terrace.A spokesman for Dundee Health and Social Care Partnership said: “All health boards across Scotland are facing a national shortage of GPs and NHS Tayside is no exception.“Despite continuing efforts, Mill Practice in Dundee, which has premises at Arthurstone Medical Centre and Fintry Mill Medical Centre, has been unsuccessful in recruiting GPs to fill three practice vacancies.“A public engagement exercise was led by Dundee Health and Social Care Partnership in conjunction with Fintry Mill Practice and a report was presented to the meeting of the Integration Joint Board held on August .“In order for the practice to continue to provide the best service for all registered patients, the decision was taken by Mill Practice to permanently close its Fintry Mill branch on Friday October .“All patients registered with Fintry Mill Practice have been notied of the closure date explaining that after this date patients will be seen at the Mill Practice.”Fintry Community Council chairman Ron Neave said the situation was a “shambles”.He added: “This is a devastating situation for the community.“It is going to affect everyone in the community who goes to the practice, including the elderly, disabled and vulnerable.“The practice had only recently taken on patients from the Stobswell Medical Practice which was also forced to close earlier this year.“It’s a complete shambles. It means that people are now going to have to travel much further afield to see a doctor.”

title: dundee street artists to take on europe in competition
story: Dundee has been selected alongside street art centres in Italy and Spain as one of the cities to feature in a European competition.Travel the Wall will see artists from Dundee submit any of their spray paint artwork on the city’s Mary Ann Lane, with the winner bagging a trip to Barcelona.The alley, near Dundee Bus Station, contains a designated “free wall” where anyone can go to paint, mirroring spaces in cities across the world.Artists in Parma and Aberdeen will also compete on their respective free walls for a trip to Spain, while those in Barcelona will compete for a trip to Scotland or Italy.The competition is being organised by Wallspot, a body which promotes collaboration between street artists in  countries worldwide.Dundee’s involvement is being orchestrated by OpenClose, a project which has seen neglected spaces around the city transformed by artwork.Russel Pepper, a PhD student who set up OpenClose, described the competition as “awesome”.He said: “As far as I know, this is the first time Dundee has worked with other cities in Europe.”

title: neil mccann backs his dundee players to handle the heat
story: Dundee will have to face a dferent kind of pressure this weekend against Kilmarnock but manager Neil McCann is backing his players to handle it once again.The Dark Blues boss was full of praise for the way his defence dealt with Hamilton’s direct approach in the second half of their - victory.Accies brought on strikers Rakish Bingham and on-loan Mason Bloomfield as they bombarded the Dundee defensive line.However, with the help of the crossbar a couple of times, Dundee held out and lted some of the heat that’s been on the manager and his team after the six straight defeats that began their season.With Killie’s attacking line of Greg Stewart, Eamonn Brophy, Jordan Jones, Chris Burke and Kris Boyd it’ll be a dferent sort of pressure the Dark Blues will have to be ready to deal with.Neil, though, expects the edginess in their defending as they homed in on their first win to be gone come Saturday.He said: “The next game will be a tough one against Kilmarnock but we enjoyed last weekend because it had been a long time coming.“Against Hamilton, I knew they would go direct, they brought Bingham on and did go more direct.“You have to deal with that – there is only so much you can do as a manager, tactically, and the players have to deal with it.“You have to be able to deal with the threat of them going direct.“There was a wee bit of edge still in their game because I’ve been saying for weeks I’d love to see them go in front and see what it did to their game.“I always knew they would still be playing with pressure but they dealt with that.“They had to deal with long balls, there were a couple of balls flashed across the goal but I thought we were well worth our three points last Saturday.”Meanwhile, a Dundee reserve side including first-teamers Jack Hamilton, Darren O’Dea, Jesse Curran and Jean Mendy were thrashed - by Dunfermline at Kelty Hearts’ New Central Park.It was Jimmy Boyle’s men’s first defeat in the Reserve League with goals from Lewis McCann, two from former Dundee United man Robbie Muirhead and second-half penalties from Tom Beadling and Myles Hippolyte counting for the Pars.The match did see a first outing for new Dee signing Grant Nelson.The -year-old from Rangers signed up with Boyle’s reserve side before the contest.

story: Dundee United fans have given a clear indication that they want a new face to take charge at the club, an exclusive Tele poll has revealed.The Tangerines are on the hunt for a new manager after the departure of Csaba Laszo on Sunday.A number of names have been linked with the position, including long-term assistant Laurie Ellis.However, Arabs who took part in our online poll have come out in favour of former Hearts gaffer Robbie Neilson.The -year-old, whose last spell as a manager was at MK Dons, received % of the voteafter , people took part in the poll.Current interim boss Laurie Ellis came second with % of fans backing him to take the hotseat on a permanent basis.Both Neilson and Ellis are currently the bookies# joint favourites to take on the role permanently.St Johnstone gaffer Tommy Wright was third on the fans# wish list at % # however, in reality the chances of the Northern Irishman coming to manage at Tannadice are slim to none.The poll results in full :Robbie Neilson Laurie Ellis       Tommy Wright Jim McIntyre    Terry Butcher   Billy McKinlay John Hughes     Dick Campbell  Paul Sturrock    Billy Dodds      Ian McCall       Steven Pressley John Robertson Other                 Of the respondents,  people selected the #other# category and suggested other names including former United man Barry Robson, legendary forward Duncan Ferguson, Maurice Malpas and Ian Cathro.Supporter Dave Stewart commented on the poll suggesting Danny Lennon takes charge.He wrote: #Laurie Ellis is guilty by association with the last two failures.#One Tommy Wright voter commented: #We need an experienced manager # no more ex players or inexperienced men.#Robbie Neilson supporters felt he had a decent track record in the SPFL to take the job.One wrote: #It has to be someone that has been in top flight football before. title: private firm with profits of 1m last year hikes up cost of ninewells parking yet again
story: Visitors to Ninewells Hospital are set to fork out more cash for parking after another rise in fees was announced.Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd, which operates the facility’s car parks on behalf of NHS Tayside as part of a contract signed several years ago, will raise its daily charge by p to £. from next month.Annual staff permits are set to rise from £. to £..It follows similar hikes in recent years which have sparked anger among patients and staff.Indigo reported a £. million profit in , up .% on the previous year, due to “an increase in parking tarfs”, according to documents filed with Companies House.The company took on a contract to manage Ninewells’ parking in  on a -year deal.It would cost NHS Tayside millions of pounds to buy out the agreement, and both health and government chiefs have repeatedly ruled out such a move.Margaret Watt, recently retired honorary chairman of the Scottish Patients Association, said: “These parking companies should be ashamed of themselves.“They are targeting patients and their relatives at a very vulnerable time in their lives when people can be very unwell, or even on their final days.“Somebody should make these parking companies share these massive profits where they are needed at a time when the NHS is struggling.“The effect on hospital staff is also unacceptable .”Fraser Macpherson, Lib Dem councillor for the West End ward, which includes Ninewells, said: “These increases not only put pressure on the pockets of patients, their families and staff, it also puts pressure on side streets near the hospital.#Signing up for this contract, which still has another  years to run, was not the cleverest thing for NHS Tayside to do and they are stuck with it.”NHS Tayside said it would be inappropriate to comment.Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd had not responded to a request for comment as the Tele went to press.

title: winner dundee named europes most visionary city for electric vehicles at japan ceremony
story: Dundee was named as the most visionary city in Europe for electric vehiclesat a ceremony in Japan.The World Electric Vehicle Association presented the city council with an E-visionary award for its pioneering initiatives to encourage the use of EVs at its annual gathering in Kobe.The council was put forward for the award by industry body the Electric Vehicle AssociationScotland.City development convener Lynne Short said the council was “truly honoured” to win the award.She added: “It’s fantastic that our work to improve transport and air quality for the people of Dundee is also providing inspiration for other cities around the world.”About % of Dundee City Council’s own fleet of cars and vans is electric, and % of the city’s taxis are zero-emission.Work also started this week on Dundee’s fourth electric vehicle mass-charging centre.

title: Fee introduction was a factor in recyling rate dip but just a blip insists Highland Council
story: THE controversial introduction of the fee for emptying brown bins was a factor in the arearsquos dip in recycling rates last year.But Highland Council chiefs say it was just a blip.While the level of household waste recycled nationally exceeded the amount sent to landfill for the first time, the tonnage slipped in Highland.The regionrsquos  recycling feat of . per cent dropped last year to . per cent ndash and last year a pound charge was brought in for emptying garden waste bins. This fee was increased to pound this year.The councilrsquos vice convener Allan Henderson, who also is also chairman of the environment committee, said: ldquoWhile wersquore getting better at recycling, the change to charging for brown bins has meant some garden waste being channelled into municipal waste.ldquoI believe our proposal to build a lsquomaterial recovery facilityrsquo and roll out extra brown bin coverage will reverse this slight dip.The latest figures from the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyshow that recycling rates improved at  of Scotlandrsquos  local authorities.It estimates that . per cent of waste generated in Scotland was recycled, which was an annual increase of . per cent.Scotlandrsquos environment secretary Roseanna Cunningham welcomed the figures but said more progress was needed, particularly in the cities.The biggest increases in recycling rates were in West Lothian, East Renfrewshire, Dumfries and Galloway, South Ayrshire and Aberdeen City.Ms Cunningham said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has big plans for tackling waste plastics, in particular by introducing a depositscheme, to further incentivise people to recycle.ldquoWersquove also introduced a household recycling charter for local authorities to sign up to, which is making the approach to recycling less confusing for households and creating a more consistent and efficient system for authorities.The Sepa figures show the amount of household waste generated in Scotland was . million tonnes in  ndash a decrease of , tonnes from .Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Gaelic centre plan has backing of Inverness public
story: A SURVEY has shown that there is signicant public support for a new Gaelic cultural centre in Inverness.The research, which was carried out by the Alba Heritage Trust with the aim of establishing the level of interest in a project celebrating Gaelic heritage, was met with ldquooverwhelming backing from members of the public.Alba Heritage Trust director Alastair Forbes says the reaction has from businesses and iniduals across the board has been signicant.ldquoWe are delighted to have had so many responses to the survey, he said.ldquoThe reaction from the public and private sectors and from members of the community for the establishment of a Gaelic cultural centre has been extremely positive which has given us great confidence in moving forward with the project.Dr Blackrsquos Memorial Hall in the city centre has already been earmarked as a potential venue for the initiative ndash backed by an architectural survey.Plans for potential facilities in the centre include a Gaelic cafeacute, a retail space selling Gaelic-themed products, and language classes as well as a cultural exhibition.It would also host ceilidhs, shows and performances, as well as talks and lectures on the subject of Gaelic culture.Alba Heritage Trust director Emily Macdonald said: ldquoA cultural centre of this type would be of great benefit to the city of Inverness and the wider Highland area.ldquoIt would provide a focal point for anyone with an interest in Gaelic language and culture.ldquoThe potential impacts include promoting Gaelic language and culture, increasing Gaelic usage, encouraging community interaction, attracting further cultural events to the city, creating jobs and enhancing Invernessrsquos offering as a centre for tourism.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Highland Council shouldnt have to shoulder cost of Universal Credit introduction argues MP
story: Inverness and Nairn MP Drew Hendry is calling on the UK government to meet the additional burden and is also seeking an urgent meeting with Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey.It follows a similar demand from council leader Margaret Davidson who says the costs should not be met by Highland council tax and rent payers.Inverness was first chosen in  as the only place in Scotland to trial the much-criticised welfare reform which was implemented in the city two years ago and in the rest of the Highlands last year.Despite tales from claimants facing a tide of debt and dficulties ndash many of which were highlighted in the Inverness Courier ndash it is also being rolled out across the UK.But Mr Hendry described the move as ldquoshambolic and said people in the Highlands were having to subsidise the government for its failed project.ldquoDay in, day out, Highland Council staff have to deal with a system littered with inefficiencies and a host of process failures ndash costing not only more time for officers but lots more money from the councilrsquos budget, he said. ldquoIn addition to meeting administration costs, Highland Council is also having to burden the cost of rent arrears which have shot through the roof because of theof time people and landlords have to wait for payments. It simply cannot go on.According to figures obtained by Mr Hendry, the council spent pound, between - to administer universal credit but only received pound, from the government, leaving a gap of pound,.The figures also showed more than half the councilrsquos pound. million in rent arrears was directly attributable to the new system.Mr Hendry warned with nearly , people in the Highlands still to be transferred to universal credit the bill would continue to rise.Councillor Davidson also wrote to Ms McVey in August seeking full reimbursement of the costs but is still awaiting a reply.ldquoThe council continues to support claimants who are impacted by universal credit as a result of flaws in the system, Cllr Davidson said.But the councilrsquos Conservative leader Andrew Jarvie said lessons had been learned and issues ironed out.ldquoIt is easy to look at headline figures and see the situation gets blown out of all proportion, he said. ldquoPrior to universal credit, housing rent arrears were about pound million.A spokesman for the Department of Work and Pensions said support was provided for claimants as they moved to universal credit while a flexible payment system had been introduced in Scotland.ldquoRent arrears are complicated and they cannot be attributed to a single cause, he said. ldquoOur research shows that many people join universal credit with pre-existing arrears but the proportion of people with arrears falls by a third after four months on universal credit.-Drew Hendry will hold a welfare surgery on Friday for anyone struggling with benefit or welfare issues as part of the Poverty Alliancersquos Challenge Poverty Week.It will take place between noon and pm at Merkinch Community Centre.Other organisations taking part include Highland Council, Citizens Advice Bureau, Inverness Cathedral, Advocacy Highland, Employability Skills and Welfare Project, and MFR Cash for Kids.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Port cruises to best ever year
story: THE Port of Cromarty Firth recorded its best ever year in , with almost pound million in turnover, it has reported.Its annual review reports a turnover of pound. million ndash pound million higher than its previous turnover record in .A ersication from its core business of oil and gas to renewables, decommissioning and cruise and a higher number of vessels than expected resulted in the improvement. Many of the visitors have been taken by coach to hot spots such as Inverness and Loch Ness.The strong results will allow the port at Invergordon to continue to invest in major developments, such as the new quayside and laydown space, which is in the planning stages for construction through Chief executive Bob Buskie said: ldquoAt the start of , with low oil and gas prices, we knew the port had to adapt to sustain our growth and help keep local people in work.ldquoFirstly, supporting our core customers in oil and gas was a key concern.ldquoAfter the necessary consultation, we introduced a new pricing for statutory dues in January , which meant an average five per cent reduction in fees for most clients, supporting them through the downturn.ldquoSecondly, the port had to look to the future and see what we could do to help sustain jobs and growth.The cruise-liner market was a success last year, with the port being named as the busiest in Scotland. It welcomed  ships and more than , passengers mdash a  per cent increase on . The direct spend from passengers is put at pound million.The port has outlined plans to build a new multi-use berth development to provide modern facilities and to accommodate the larger cruise ships.The port also ran two workshops, in conjunction with the cruise companies and Highlands and Islands Enterprise, to help local businesses understand and work with this lucrative sector. A cruise stakeholder group was also established to help improve logistics and communication.Port board chairman Douglas Russell said hard work by its staff saw produced the record-breaking year.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Pressure on Highland Council to stub out unethical investments
story: HIGHLAND Council could review its stake-holding in tobacco, alcohol and weapons companies.Opposition to such selections was spelled out by Ross-shire councillor Angela MacLean amid long running anger about the ethics of the local authority investing millions of pounds in such industries while also claiming to promote ldquohealthy lestyles through council policies.Over the past  years, a small band of councillors has registered opposition to widely perceived ldquounethical investments but to no effect.Independent fund managers are employed to get the maximum . Recent figures showed the fund increased in value in - by pound. million. As of last weekend, it was valued at pound,,,..Addressing colleagues on the audit and scrutiny committee, Cllr MacLean called for a review of investment strategy. She acknowledged the need to secure the best .But she added: ldquoSome people are not happy with some of the investments and feel that perhapsitrsquos invested in tobacco or arms or things like that, itrsquos not ethically responsible.She asked whether fund trustees had any say in the choice of investments.The councilrsquos investments change on a daily basis.Recent examples of contentious choices include British American Tobacco , liqueurs firm Pernod Ricard , pubs chain Mitchells and Butlers , Japan Tobaccoand Chinarsquos second largest brewery, Tsingtao .The councilrsquos finance director Derek Yule explained that an investments sub-committee reports to a pension board which sets the strategy.ldquoIt is very dficult when some of the investment strategy seeks to invest in shares in companies not just in the UK but worldwide, he said.ldquoWhilst I totally understand some of the ethical debate, it is very dficult to draw a line sometimes.ldquoYou might take a viewhellip would you invest in banks, for example  They might not be the best investment, anyway. But I use that as an example because banks will fund these companies.ldquoItrsquos a dficult balancing act but itrsquos certainly within your rightsyou wished the pension board to look at the investment strategy.ldquoFund managers are given guidelines to work to, so that would be quite legitimate for the council to do through the pension board.According to current policy, the fund ldquorecognises that social, environmental and ethical considerations are among factors investment managers will take into account, where relevant, when selecting investments for purchase, retention or sale.However, it stresses that ldquothe overriding consideration for pension committee members is their fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and scheme members.The Scheme Advisory Board, established up by the Scottish Government to regulate such public sector pension funds, recently obtained advice from legal counsel on the duty of pensions committees.The guidance concluded that: ldquoPensions committees in Scotland owe a fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and the scheme members in general and specically in relation to investment matters.ldquoThose duties should be exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries and in relation to investment decisions, should aim to achieve the best financial position for the fund, balancing risk andin the usual way.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Proud Ness parade temporary traffic restrictions
story: Motorists are being advised of temporary road closures in Inverness tomorrowbetween .am and .am for the Proud Ness Parade.The temporary traffic prohibitions will affect all vehicular traffic under the direction of police.The parade starts at Falcon Square, heads along Inglis Street and High Street to the Town House, then across Ness Bridge and along the river to Eden Court.The road closures are as follows:Academy Street: closed at its junction with Union Street to its junction with Inglis Street, .-.am.Inglis Street: closed at its junction with Academy Street to its junction with High Street, .-.am.High Street: closed at its junction with Eastgate to its junction with Bridge Street, .-:amBridge Street: closed at its junction with High Street to its junction with Castle Road, .-.am.Ness Bridge: closed at its junction with Bank Street to its junction with Young Street, .-.am.Ness Walk: closed at its junction with Young Street to its junction with Ardross Terrace, .-.am.Ardross Terrace: closed at its junction with Ness Walk to its junction with Ardross Street, .-.am.Ardross Street: closed at its junction with Ardross Terrace to its junction with Alexander Place, .-.am.Bishops Road: closed at its junction with Ardross Terrace to its junction with Ness Walk Upper, .-am.Bishops Road: closed at its junction with Ness Walk Upper to its junction with Bishops Park, .-.am.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Recovery cafe celebrates official launch in Inverness
story: Our Place ndash or Ar n-Aite in Gaelic ndash will make its money serving cappuccinos and macchiatos to the general public, pouring the proceeds back into the enterprise.Staff at the Church Street hub will be drawn from a pool of ex-prisoners who agree to work for free infor on-the-job training.And pensioners and other do-gooders will put their green fingers to good use growing as much free fruit and vegetables as the cafeacute needs to feed its hungry customers.But in a slight hiccup managers at the Signpost charity which is spearheading Our Place are having to meet with some traders who voiced concern crime could rocketa high concentration of ex-offenders are put under one roof.James Docherty from Scotlandrsquos Crime Reduction Unit which is backing the cafeacute said the tradersrsquo concerns were ldquoa symptom of social exclusion.ldquoSocially excluding people is more likely to cause a rise in crime, he said.ldquoWe run a similar project in Glasgow called Street and Arrow. Itrsquos police-led but facilitated by people from an offendersrsquo background and itrsquos a blinding success.And speaking at the opening launch Inverness and Nairn MP Drew Hendry said: ldquoPart of the plan for the Inverness Cafeacute on Church Street is to use vegetables locally-grown by those who use the cafe and those who work in it, and its customers.ldquoThis is named lsquoGrow your own communityrsquo ndash how apt. What is really being planted here though is the new generation, the seeds of the next crop of people who understand inclusion, equality, community and respect.Alan Fowler, community programmes manager for Signpost said: ldquoWe want to create an environment where therersquos no them and us.It has secured pound, from Highland Council and pound, from The Robertson Trust.Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Retail park plan aims to avoid major unit being left empty
story: A PLANNING application has been submitted to ide one of Invernessrsquos biggest retail units in two.Hercules Unit Trust, the owner of Inverness Shopping Park, has submitted a request to Highland Council to subide the existing Homebase store.It currently occupies the largest retail unit at the park and it was announced in August that it would be one of  Homebase stores from across the UK set to close.It is thought around  jobs in Inverness alone will be lost when it shuts by early . Job losses nationally are said to be in the region of  after Homebase entered into a company voluntary arrangement following "under-performance of the business".The applicant outlines that there is no demand for the store to be re-let as a single unit and iding the unit into two would help avoid the potential for a long-term vacancy.It is thought splitting the space would make it more appealing to potential tenants.Inverness economist Tony Mackay said: "If iding the unit into two makes it more attractive then that is a good move to make."I believe one of the occupiers is likely to be another DIY store but I do not know what the other store would be."The main problem for the retail park has been the increase in online shopping. This has been the same problem for retailers in the city centre."In light of a "city first policy" which encourages businesses to establish themselves in the city centre rather than out-of-town locations, Mr Mackay does not believe this will give the retail park an unfair advantage over more central stores.He said: "More needs to be done about the problem of online shopping on retailers. For a store like Homebase people were likely to drive there to get whatever they needed."The applicant suggested that despite the "centre first" policy this move would not be a problem because no new floor space is being created.The existing floor space would simply be split into two separate retail units.Mr Mackay said: "It is not the type of store you would be likely to find in the city centre. I would be surprisedthe council were to reject this application."Mike Smith, manager of the Inverness Business Improvement District , does not support the proposal."In my personal opinion I do not think the plan should go ahead," he said."One of the restrictions of the retail park was that there were only to be single units in section  of the Town and Country Planning Act. To ide the unit into two is going against what has already been established."This is my opinion within my role as manager and not that of Bid. I would consider submitting a formal objection to the Highland Council but I would first establish the wider views of Bid before deciding the most appropriate action to take."Providing the planning application is accepted, the two new retailers would still occupy a considerably large space.The applicant recognises that the potential new occupiers would still have a larger floor space than the other existing retail units nearby.The proposal suggests that a long-term vacancy would have a negative impact on the "vitality and viability of the commercial centre."Chief executive of Inverness Chamber of Commerce Stewart Nicol agreed that iding the unit into two would be a wise move.He said: "I think it would be a sensible and pragmatic approach to take."Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Suitable site is sought to plant trees for Commonwealth project
story: THE publicrsquos help is being sought to find a suitable location in the Inverness area to plant five trees as part of a UK-wide project sparked by the Queen.The Inverness Courier has joined forces with city MP Drew Hendry who is among more than  MPs who will be planting trees as part of the Queenrsquos Commonwealth Canopy, a network of forest conservation projects to mark her service to the Commonwealth.The trees ndash two silver birch, two rowan, and a hazel ndash have been donated in a partnership between the Woodland Trust, Sainsburyrsquos and ITV which screened The Queenrsquos Green Planet, earlier this year.Mr Hendry, SNP MP for Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey, is keen to invte suggestions for possible locations and has joined forces with the Inverness Courier as it marks its th anniversary.People have a week to submit their suggested location and why it deserves to be picked. The Courier will then run an online vote of shortlisted ideas.Potential sites could include schools, community spaces, forgotten corners, existing woodland areas, or perhaps somewhere to mark the th anniversary of the NHS or the centenary of the end of WWI.Mr Hendry said trees played an important part in shaping communities and it was fitting the public should get the chance to suggest a site.ldquoPlanting of these trees, as part of the Courierrsquos th anniversary celebrations, is symbolic of the paper itself, and the roots it has in our community for the last two hundred years," he said."Trees are an important part of our natural and cultural heritage, and to our local economy. We are home to Forestry Scotland HQ, and The Scottish School of Forestry and of course, my colleague Fergus Ewing MSP, is also the cabinet minister responsible for forestry."Trees are also play a big part in shaping our communities, therefore it is fitting that members of the public, schools and communities get the opportunity to nominate a place where these trees can be planted, as part of the Queenrsquos Commonwealth Canopy, and to mark the Inverness Courierrsquos  years milestone.Suggestions should be sent to drew.hendry.mp@parliament.uk by Friday, October .Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: Treasure found in a 1 box of goods
story: AMATEUR antiques collector Simon Grech took a punt when he spotted a box of bric-a-brac at Dingwall Auction Mart on sale for pound.But the Highland Council community warden was stunned to find buried beneath the chipped crockery and tea pots a beautul slate box hand-made by a -year-old African prisoner more than  years ago while he languished in a camp during the Boer War.The artefact, which has the prisonerrsquos initials SJP Venter scratched on its underside and is inscribed with the name Bellevue Kamp and the dates  and , is being snapped up by a notable London specialist.The expert, who collects Boer War memorabilia, has offered Mr Grech pound for the box, which is engraved with a South African folk flower mot and topped with an intricate quail bird.Mrs Grechrsquos we Marianne, who traced details about the boxrsquos original owner, said it was a "really exciting find".She said: "Simon likes to visit the Dingwall Auction Mart because he collects and fixes clocks."He came home with this box and the prisoner of war box was stuffed inside. It caught my eye so we did some research and it seems to have been made by a -year-old prisoner who was locked up in the Bellevue Kamp for prisoners of war in Simonstown, South Africa, during the Boer War."But we donrsquot know what happened to him or how the box came to be in Scotland, and we would love to find out."The couple, who stay at Balnacraig Road at Dalneigh in Inverness, contacted The Anglo-Boer War Museum in Bloemfontein, the only museum in the world dedicated solely to the Anglo-Boer Wars of  to , and they gleaned some interesting information.A historian told the couple a large number of Boers were captured in the vicinity of the Brandwater Basin in July and August of .A quick run through the names on the Bellevue Kamprsquos prisoner database reveals that Stephanus Johannes P Venter, a -year-old man from the Wepener District, was captured at Fouriesburg in July .But the young prisonerrsquos fate may never be known because no more details are held.The historian described the item as "a beautul slate box" and said it had signicant historical importance.Mrs Grechsaid it was a good thing Mr Venter had scratched his name on the box."Irsquod never have tracked this poor young guy right down to the day he was captured," she said.Praising her husbandrsquos nose for buried treasure she said: "Hersquos done really well. Hersquos only been going to the auction mart for a few months, itrsquos just a hobby, but he came back with a painting of The Alps for pound which Irsquove had valued at pound."However, she said some of his other finds were rather more questionable."The other week he bought a piano. I said lsquothatrsquos great, how are we going to get it home rsquo."He said lsquowell it was only pound, I couldnrsquot resist itrsquo."Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: USA dream awaits talented cheerleaders
story: SIX athletes from a local cheer and dance club will represent their country in America next year.Cheerleaders from Campbell Cheer and Dance have been specially selected to represent Team Scotland at the ICU World Cheer leading Championships in Orlando in the spring.The girls stepping up to the challenge are Hannah Riddoch , Lily Cameron , Briagh McMaster , Sophie Mapplebeck , Hollie Worthing , Marianna MacLean .Coach Dianne Campbell said: "I have been coaching some of the girls since they were three-years-old. It is amazing to see all their hard work pay off and to see their dreams come true."The whole club is incredibly proud of them and we are all there to support them every step of the way."It is such an amazing opportunity and all I want for them is to enjoy the experience and to do themselves proud."To qualy for the competition next year the girls auditioned in Glasgow in August this year where they were successful in impressing a  of five judges. They had to prepare a one minute routine showcasing their most advanced skills. They also had to perform a set routine that was taught to them on the day.Some  athletes from across Scotland will be competing at the ICU, where eight dferent types of cheerleading categories will feature Scottish representation.Hollie Worthing and Sophie Mapplebeck qualied for Junior Pom. Briagh McMaster, Hannah Riddoch, Mariana MacLean and Lily Cameron qualied for Senior Jazz.The girls will be competing against cheerleading teams from all over the world against teams like Mexico, Japan and Russia.The girls entering the competition next year will need to raise pound each ahead of the competition.They will also be training in Glasgow each week and need funds for travel, accommodation expenses and for the trip itself.To support the girls in their fundraising efforts ahead of the competition next year, donations can be made by contacting the clubrsquos website at www.campbellcheerCoach Dianne Campbell said training is already underway for the competition, which runs from April  to .Sunday  Oct  : AM

title: aberdeen blow away st mirren 4 1 at pittodrie
story: ABERDEEN rediscovered their cutting edge in attack as they overcame  St Mirren - at Pittodrie.The Reds were without first choice strikers James Wilson, on loan from Manchester United, and Stevie May through injury.However Sam Cosgrove and teenager Connor McLennan, on his debut, both laid down a marker by netting impressive first goals for the Dons.Both scored in  the first half before on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe made it - going into the break.Cosgrove increased his tally in the second half to make it - before Buddies grabbed a consolation.It was a bitter sweet first start for McLennan who had to come off with a shoulder injury in the th minute after falling awkwardly during a challenge from Cammy MacPherson.The absence of Wilson and May was two of four changes  to the side that lost - to Celtic at Parkhead last Saturday.Boss Derek McInnes handed a first start to -year-old striker McLennan who  grabbed his chance.The teen#s only game time for the first team this season had been the last  minutes of the - BetFred Cup win over St Mirren at Pittodrie.Cosgrove also ed to the starting line-up along with on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe.Having recovered from a knee injury that had ruled him out of the last three matches midfielder Lewis Ferguson also went straight back into the starting XI,Scotland international defender Scott McKenna was suspended having been handed a controversial two game ban retrospectively for a challenge on Celtic#s Odsonne Edouard.Northern Ireland cap Niall McGinn was also ruled out through injury.St Mirren created the first opportunity in the eighth minute when Simeon Jackson drove at goal before firing just wide from  yards.Aberdeen#s first signicant opportunity came when a Max Lowe drive from  yards was deflected wide of the St Mirren goal by Cosgrove.Next they threatened via a powerful low  yard drive from Gary Mackay-Steven in the st minute that flashed inches wide of keeper Craig Samson#s goal.The opener came in the th minute when Shay Logan whipped in a cross from the right into the penalty area.COSGROVE met the ball with a ing header at full stretch and brilliantly directed it into the far corner beyond keeper  Samson.Only the woodwork stopped it being - moments later when Mackay-Steven danced over the ball and then unleashed a  yard curling effort that cracked off the far post.Teenager MCLENNAN marked his first start in style with a superb goal.He collected a Logan pass on the half-turn and bent a magnicent  yard drive that crashed off the underside of the bar and over the line.It was - and game over for a broken St Mirren in the st minute when Mackay-Steven’s shot deflected to Max LOWE who was left completely unmarked with the goal beckoning.He calmly slotted in from  yards.Aberdeen should have been awarded a penalty in the rd minute when McLennan broke from the left flank into the box.He was pulled back by Jack Baird in the box who clearly impeded him as McLennan fired off a shot. Referee Alan Muir waved play on.In the th minute McLennan went on a rampaging run down the left flank, alluded three challenges before rling a powerful drive into the side netting.Moments later Aberdeen nearly conceded a bizarre goal when Lewis# clearance richoched off the back of Jackson.The ball spun up towards goal and Lewis had to race back to palm the ball off the line. He redeemed his mistake with a superb save.Unfortunately goal scorer McLennan was taken off with a shoulder injury in the th minute having fallen awkwardly after a tackle. He was replaced by Chris Forrester.It was - in the th minute when COSGROVE latched onto a cross from the byline from Lowe who whipped in an instinctive left footed shot.Keeper Samson got both hands onto the waist high shot and pushed it onto the post and it went over the line.St Mirren grabbed a consolation in the th when the Aberdeen defence switched off and former Don Cammy Smith picked up consolation and crossed to JACKSON who was unmarked and dinked it over Lewis.Aberdeen: Lewis, Logan, Devlin, Considine, Lowe, Ball, Shinnie, Ferguson, Mackay-Steven, McLennan, Cosgrove.Subs: Forrester , Gleeson , Anderson Subs not used: Cerny, Campbell, Mackenzie, E. Ross.ST MIRREN: Samson, P. McGinn, S. McGinn, Flynn, Jackson, Baird, Hodson, Edwards, MacPherson, Ferdinand, Hammill.Subs: McShane , Smith Subs not used: Lyness, Heaton, Kirkpatrick,  Jamieson, Erhahon.Referee: Alan Muir

title: gym and cafe offer kemnay residents social benefits too1
story: Kemnay residents can enjoy a good workout, a delicious meal and socialise all under the same roof.Café and Station Gym have been open for  months and have been offering a one-of-a-kind facility for locals.Owner Alan Findlater said: “This building is the first of its kind in Kemnay – we have the usual studio, weights and cardio but with the café there’s also the added social element. It’s become a great way to get together – you can go from your workout to have a coffee and a chat in just a few steps.”Gym users can pick whether to go for day passes or memberships . There are also personal training options available for users.Classes include Metafit, yoga and spin – so whether you want to work up a sweat or stay flexible, there’s plenty on offer.The gym is open from am to pm Monday to Friday, am to pm on Saturday and am to pm on Sundays.Meanwhile, Sundays to Wednesdays the café is open from am to pmfor coffee, home-baking and healthy food, including soups and sandwiches.But Thursdays to Saturdays, the restaurant is also open until pm for evening meals, with tapas, sharing boards and healthy eats on the menu. There’s even a specially kiddies menu – and between  and pm kids eat free!Follow the Station Gym and Café  on Facebook.

title: community groups to be given chance to take over north east woodland
story: North-east community groups will be given the opportunity to put themselves forward to take over a woodland area at a public meeting.The Forestry Commission is looking to launch a community buyout of Clochandighter Hill near Portlethen.Suggestions have been made for the hill to be used for recreational activities such as biking and orienteering.Portlethen and District Community Council chairman Ron Sharp said: “The Forestry Commission is looking to sell on the land at Clochandighter Hill and are looking to find a community group that will take it on.”Now, organisations are being urged to consider taking over the hill in a community buyout.A meeting will be held at Hillside School with all interested groups encouraged to attend.Ron said: “We have seen some interest from a few groups but nothing has been set in stone.“We have been working closely with North Kincardine Rural Community Council on this.“This meeting will be an ideal place for all interested parties to come along to seewe can get this going.“As the community council, we cannot take this on ourselves but we are very happy to encourage others to get involved and consider taking on the area.”He added: “In the right hands, the plans for the hill could be great.“We are very enthusiastic about this option and there have been plenty of examples where community buyouts have been very effective.“It would be great to have in the hands of a community group and I would really encourage local groups to come along to the meeting to learn more about it all.”The meeting to discuss the buyout will take place on Tuesday at pm.A spokesman for Forest Enterprise Scotland said: “This scheme is a great opportunity for communities across Scotland to acquire publicly-owned forest resources – whether that’s land or buildings – that they feel they can make better use of for the benefit of their community.”

title: dancers aim for leg up on funds1
story: A dance school is one of many hoping to scoop part of a £, cash giveaway.Dansation, a freestyle dance school in the city, is tossing its hat in the ring in this year’s CommunitEE Chest.Adele McIntosh-Smith, a parent who helps fundraise for the school, said: “We are taking part in the CommunitEE Chest competition this year to help raise funds in order to help the girls compete at competitions across the country.“The parents help fundraise where they can and we hope to help the girls take part in competitions in England.“Dansation is a freestyle disco and slow dance school, there are not many of these schools in Aberdeen.”The school sees a erse range of students from four to  years old.She added: “There are currently eight girls ranging from the ages of five up to  who make up the competition team, they are all very hard working and dedicated and have a great sense of team spirit which shows every time they compete.“They train three to four days a week at the studio which is situated within Pinnacle Fitness at The Arches on South College street.”To be in with a chance of landing a share of the £, prize money, all organisations which are registered must collect more than  tokens from the Evening Express.Tokens can be collected daily – with TWO tokens in every day next week!

title: efforts to make rough sleeping a thing of past
story: Three north-east charities are hoping a new scheme will eradicate homelessness in the region.Aberdeen Cyrenians, Turning Point Scotland and Aberdeen Foyer are part of a consortium, along with Aberdeen City and Aberdeenshire councils, to deliver Housing First.The programme aims to provide accommodation for homeless people with complex needs, as well as “wrap around” support for a iety of issues that may impact on their ability to hold a tenancy, including mental health or addiction issues.Housing First is due to be rolled out across the country, with  properties in five cities being released for use, including  in the city and Aberdeenshire.The initiative will be funded by money raised as part of Social Bite’s Sleep in the Park, where people raise cash by spending a night sleeping outside.Mike Burns, CEO of Aberdeen Cyrenians, hopes the scheme will stop rough sleeping in the north-east.He said: “The Housing First programme has been successful in Finland and Canada.“If we can have the same success here in Scotland, and particularly in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire, then hopefully we can get to the stage where rough sleeping will be a thing of the past.“The circumstances around homelessness will continue, people will still have dficulties in le, butour systems are better and more rapidly delivered then we can stop that happening.”Last year Aberdeen Cyrenians dealt with , people who presented themselves as rough sleeping, homeless or almost homeless. The process of moving people into properties pledged to Housing First in the north-east is under way and it is hoped the first participants will be in tenancies by the end of this month.Patrick McKay, the operations manager for Turning Point, pointed to a similar pilot run by the charity in Glasgow.In , in response to a rise in drug deaths in the city, Turning Point started a Housing First scheme.Patrick said: “We’ve been doing it since , in collaboration with the local authority, as a response to the drug deaths in Glasgow. It’s brilliant these people are being given a tenancy for the first time, and they’re in their s or s.“They talk about things like what it’s like to have your very own front door. But the dference in Housing First is the amount of support that people are getting at any one time.”Aberdeen Foyer chief executive Leona McDermid said: “We’ll be providing the youth element of Housing First in the north-east, that’s our particular level of expertise – working with - to -year-olds with a iety of complex needs.#It’s a slightly dferent offer that you needyou’re a young person who is homeless, especially when you’re making that jump into adulthood.”

title: nursery helps spruce up hospice playroom
story: Nursery pupils helped to bring a splash of colour to an Aberdeen hospice as they opened a new playroom.Children from the Little Acorn Nursery visited Roxburghe House in Aberdeen to officially open its newly-refurbished playroom after helping to raise £, for its transformation. vw, px"  The room, now complete with toys, games and an interactive television screen, is now available for patients of all ages and relatives of older patients.After completing a sponsored walk along the Beach Esplanade, the pupils donated to the room’s revamp to join the efforts of the Friends of Roxburghe House Grampian charity.The revamp also benefited from a donation from the hospice’s SPAR store. vw, px"  Treasurer of the group Peter Clark said: “We identied the play area as being in need of refurbishment two years ago so it has been a long time in the making.“The donations from SPAR and the Little Acorns nursery have helped to transform the room.“Though Roxburghe House is primarily for adults, there are children who stay here and many who visit so this can provide some respite for them.#Roxburghe House’s SPAR also contributed to the appeal by donating £, accrued by the p bag charge.When it came to redesigning the formerly plain room, NHS activities co-ordinator Liz McDonald conducted research.She said: “I’ve been involved in the project from the start and at times it felt like it would never be finished so it is great to see it being used.“I visited playrooms in the Royal Aberdeen Children’s Hospital and CLAN to see what we could try, and we asked ex-service users and their relatives for their opinions.“We made it colourful to attract the little children but we added the ‘pod’ chair for the older children. It has chargers nearby and blocks out the sound around you, so it will be good for when they are having a hard time and just want to get away from it all.Henry McBain, , cut the ceremonial ribbon – with child-friendly scissors – and said: “I like the Lego the best.” vw, px"

title: plans submitted for new cattery in north east town
story: Plans have been lodged to build a new cattery near a north-east town.Proposals submitted to Aberdeenshire Council seek permission for the formation of a cattery and to build cattery pens at The Paddock Stables, Banchory.Planning documents state: “The proposed cattery aims to directly replace a small timber stable block which has fallen into disrepair.“The cattery buildings will directly replace the stables and will be similar in height and overall size.”There would be  pens in total.They add: “Cats kept on site will not be permitted to roam freewithin the times of their care at this facility. This will therefore avoid any issues with local wildle.”If approved the proposals promise the cattery would “generate additional employment as additional staff will be needed for their care or for any grooming services”.

title: reserve upgrade cash1
story: A nature reserve has been awarded £, of funding for upgrades to be carried out.The cash will be used to make improvements to the car parking and toilets at Muir of Dinnet, situated close to the village of Dinnet.The funding, from the Rural Tourism Infrastructure Fund, will also provide waste disposal areas to address demand and prevent roadside parking.Convener of the Cairngorms National Park Authority and local councillor Peter Argyle welcomed the funding news.He said: “It’s really good news and we’re really very pleased.“I’d like to give a huge thank you to everybody who worked with us to secure this funding for Muir of Dinnet.”Around £ million from the first round of the fund will be shared among  projects across Scotland to help meet the demand of growing visitor numbers at the country’s most iconic, rural tourist sites.Fellow ward councillor Geva Blackett said: “This is very good news and it will make much-needed improvements to what is an incredibly popular visitors’ site.”But Ms Blackett added it was “hugely disappointing” to learn an application to have the car park at Ballater resurfaced was unsuccessful.She added: “Parking is a real issue in Ballater but hopefully we can have a go in the next round of funding.”Tourism Secretary Fiona Hyslop said: “This funding will help our industry keep up with the tourism boom by supporting the creation of much-needed infrastructure such as new pathways, car parks and facilities at some of our most iconic rural and natural attractions.”Malcolm Roughead, chief executive of VisitScotland, said: “The Scottish Government Rural Tourism Infrastructure Fund will help these communities improve their facilities and enhance their offering to welcome more visitors in the future.”

title: 034ex0510eea_story__1 fn 2
story: Jamie Watt has urged Banks o’ Dee to grasp their chance to make Evening Express Aberdeenshire Cup history.The Junior Superleague champions take on Cove Rangers tonight at Harlaw Park in the final of the Shire Cup.The trophy was first played for in  and has never been won by a Junior side.Although Aberdeen University did lt the cup in  , they were not a Junior side at the time.Dee co-manager Watt, who’s in charge at Spain Park along with Tommy Forbes, wants to see his side embrace their opportunity to make history.He said: “History is there for us, we want to grasp that.“We’re a Junior team and you’d expect us to be just competing in the first and second rounds and then going out.“But we’ve built something special here and we know that, we keep asking them to perform in the games with Highland League teams and the boys keep turning up.“History is definitely there and it puts the club on the map as well, so fingers crossed we can get the result.“I’ve been emphasising to the boys that it would be huge for the clubwe could win this cup.“Just getting to the final is massive. I played Highland League for a long time and this is a hard final to get to.“So to go that next step and win the cup would be huge.“It would be a big reward for Brian Winton, the president, and the committee because the people behind the scenes do a lot and it’s them who get the reward.“Me and Tommy Forbes have a good team and they know they are a good team – but to go that extra step and beat Cove to win the cup would be fantastic.”Watt has stepped into management this season alongside Forbes after Sandy McNaughton stepped down at the end of last season.Watt says it would be a dream to win his first trophy in management tonight.He added: “I’m a born winner, I love winning and hate losing.“As a manager it’s completely dferent standing on the sidelines.“But I’ve enjoyed management so far, everything has been great.“If this was to be the first trophy on the board it would be a dream in a cup of this magnitude.”On their road to the final Dee have beaten Inverurie Locos, Aberdeen Reserves and Turrf United. Watt says they will have taken confidence from those results, but doesn’t expect it to be easy against Cove.He said: “We do take confidence from the results we’ve had in the cup this year and in the last two seasons in the Shield.“Apart from the finals where we lost we’ve had good results against pretty much everyone.“Cove’s the only team that we haven’t really beaten and we only played them in last season’s Shield final.“But we’ll go into this final confident, looking for a good performance and we’ll see what happens.“We know they’re dominating the Highland League – they are the best team in the Highland League and they’ll want to stop our run in the cup.”

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column week 34

title: science matters week 36
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated -days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as  pence per week.The multi-million dollar international trade in exotic pets has long been a bugbear of mine.Not only does it promote wild animals asfashion accessories, but it also allows potentially dangerous microbes to jump to, and cause epidemics in, other species including humans. What’s more, eventhey don’t mutate as occurred in the case outlined here,released into the wild either by design or mistake these foreigners can cause havoc to local ecosystems.In a letter to the scientic journal Nature in , a group of German scientists began ‘it has been rumoured that an unidentied crayfish…of marbled appearance and uncertain geographical origin that was introduced into the German aquarium trade in the mid s, is capable of unisexual reproduction ’.The authors ended by warning that: ‘This crayfish…could become a menace to European freshwater systems, as the release of even one specimen into the wild would be enough to found a population that might out-compete native crayfish’.Now,  years later, this all-female crayfish has escaped into the wild.  Identied as a descendent of the fresh water slough crayfish from Florida, it is now called the marbled crayfish or Marmokrebs. So far it has invaded the waterways of at least nine European countries as well as Japan and Madagascar. Unravelling its origin reveals that a unique macro-mutation must have occurred in a single slough crayfish egg probably caused by heat or cold shock whilst in transit from Florida to Germany for the pet market.The resulting female hatchling possessed three sets of chromosomes per celland the ability to produce clones of itself without a mate and at very high frequency.Because of its warm climate and abundant freshwater habitats, Madagascar has seen the most rapid colonisation with Marmokrebs. Millions of the animals have invaded the countries lakes, rice paddies and swamps and are threatening its seven endemic crayfish species.It is only a matter of time before this scenario is repeated in other locations, destroying valuable ecosystems and eliminating indigenous species.

title: letters to the editor week 37
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated -days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as  pence per week.Sir,It is always a delight when a letter awakens a landowner.James F Lithgow#s insult about ‘blow-ins’ is a typical trait. I worked extremely hard to buy my farm, not being able to piggyback on my forebears’ efforts, and I didn’t ‘blow-in’, it took two forty-foot pantechnicons four days.It is clear he has an interest in wind turbines, and no doubt with a pair of wellies, a fish farm or two. His blinkered refusal to accept the huge body of evidence regarding fish farm contamination suggests he has an investment and it needs protecting. But only, of course,you don’t have a commercial interest.There is a huge amount of evidence that mechanical kelp harvesting does irreparable damage to the sea bed. Could I draw your readers# attention to the Facebook page #Stop Mechanical Kelp Dredging# The sea bed can’t be seen, but a bank statement can. No prizes for who is the loser. The  jobs in aquaculture will not last longmass kelp harvesting is allowed to decimate sub-sea environments and the only jobs on fish farms will be pushing barrows of diseased and dead fish.I’ve no doubt he knows that wind turbines have a -year le span and then the hugely disruptive process will start againan alternative has not been discovered. It has been calculated that the energy costs of a wind turbine will never be recovered during its lespan, but those receiving grants really don’t care.Why, given the amount of rainfall in Argyll, are hydro schemes not pursued  It used to be a mystery, until one looks at the vast sums of subsidy given by a gullible government to so called ‘alternative energy sources’, which actually means ‘alternative revenue sources’.There are any number of pretty glens that could be dammed, providing an extra environmentally-friendly leisure resource, create an opportunity for aquaculture and would not require a replacement somewhere down the line.Alexander Hamilton, Tayvallich.Sir,With reference to James Lithgow’s letter of September , it is important to make a couple of points.Mr Lithgow is right to say kelp has been sustainably harvested in Argyll for generations. There can be no comparison, however, with the current proposal to mechanically dredge up entire stands from the seabed together with all the fragile le that depends on them. This is not sustainable as evidenced in the few countries which have allowed this practice to take place.  Seaweed cultivation, on the other hand, is sustainable and more can be found on this through the Scottish Association for Marine Science.The  parliamentary inquiry into the environmental impact of salmon farming warned current methods could cause #irrecoverable damage#.  This is deeply concerning to those of us who live here, raise families and rely on the sea for our creel fishing, shellfish and tourism businesses. We also all have an inherent responsibility to care for our environment and there is increasing urgency to do this.Enterprises do need to be encouraged to grow and to provide opportunities and employment. This, however, must be done responsibly and with thought for the long-term viability of our communities.The profits of the predominantly multi-national salmon farming companies, who benefit from current loopholes in our environmental regulations, are well able to fund a responsible and researched approach for sustainability and erse employment opportunities. Norway, for example, is encouraging its salmon farmers to adopt closed containment and these methods are working well in a number of other countries, including the USA.The council has a legal responsibility for the environment and needs to take precautions for the future of Argyll, not just for job numbers today.If short-term interests are prioritised, all of our futures will be much the poorer.Will Self, on behalf of Friends of the Sound of JuraSir,Most schools in Scotland have pipers and drummers within their pupil population.Schools in Argyll are probably no exception. May I please ask your readers to seek out their pipers and encourage them to represent their school as a piping quartet,not as a full band, at the next Scottish Schools Pipe Band Championships The championships are organised annually by the Scottish Schools Pipes and Drums Trust. The next championships will be held at Inveralmond Community High School, Livingston, on Sunday March  .More details are on our website # www.thechampionships.Last March,  schools from Scotland and two from England were represented at the championships, with a category for all standards of playing.Five years ago we introduced a new category of #freestyle#.  The aim of this is to provide an opportunity for schools to showcase their other musical skills alongside those of their pipers.The Scottish Schools Pipes and Drums Trusthopes many young pipers and drummers from Mid Argyll # with other musicians tooentering the freestyle event – will participate in next year’s championships.Patrick Gascoigne, administrator, Scottish Schools Pipe Band Championships.

title: letters to the editor week 38
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated -days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as  pence per week.As I predicted in my letter of August , there would be howls of anguish from the wind farm industry, addicted as they are to a steady flow of cash from the public, at the merest mention that tidal power would be preferable to wind regarding the provision of a dependable and predictable electricity supply.What I did not predict was that the only response would come from someone who mistook the electric eel and the ray depicted in Ann Thomas#s cartoon, eagerly dining on #free# electricity, for an attack on the fish farming industry. Fish generate their own electricity by biological means, you see, and so have no need for charging points.Perhaps I shouldn#t even try to explain the joke to Mr Lithgow.I had hoped for a more cogent critique of the points I made, rather than the amateurish attempt to cover his lack of reasoning by smearing my origins and character, or what he erroneously imagines them to be, and by repeating the endless waffle of the wind industry#s PR department.One example: whenever a new wind farm is proposed there is a claim that it will provide electricity for a certain number of homes, say ,. What is not mentioned, however, except in very fine print at the bottom of the page, is that these figures are only achievable under perfect wind conditions, which rarely occur, and that the real output of usable electricity is a small fraction of the headline figure.What is also not mentioned is who is going to pay for the decommissioning costs when the wind farms inevitably turn into junk. Somehow, I don#t think it will be those who benefited financially. More likely, it will be us, the public, already being fleeced by inflated electricity bills, who will have to pay to haul thousands of tons of unrecyclable trash from our mountains or live forever with enormous eyesores.Let me restate the case for tidal power. The tides are generated by the moon as it orbits the Earth which creates gravitational pull on the oceans. These tides are predictable, both in power and timing, for centuries in advance, and will carry on being so until the moon eventually flies off into space some billions of years hence. There are two incoming tides and two outgoing every day, a total of four, each one involving an enormous quantity of moving water and thereby presenting the opportunity to generate electricity, totally free of carbon dioxide emissions.The UK, and especially Scotland, has an enormousof coastline. Scotland#s coast is about , kilometres, and Argyll accounts for a very high proportion of this because of the legacy of the last ice age which left us with such a convoluted coastline. So we have plenty of scope to exploit this resource.And we are doubly blessed because the complexity of our coastline results in the tides reaching dferent points at dferent times of the day. Therefore, by using several dferent sites, we could have an even amount of electricity always on tap.Wind and solar power cannot match this, either in quantity of power or dependability. They require a duplicate system of nuclear, coal, gas, and oil-fired generators always fired up and ready to kick in when the wind and sun refuse to co-operate # an enormously expensive system both in money and CO emissions.There is a case for subsidies during the infancy of any industry to get it started off.But the wind farm industry is not an infant # it is now a fully grown cuckoo. It has never has earned its keep and never will so it is time to chuck it out of the nest.Stuart White, Minard.Friday September  is World Alzheimer’s Day.There are , people with dementia in Scotland and , people with dementia across Argyll and Bute. It is our country’s most pressing public health issue – one we must address now, collectively.Scotland has made a lot of progress over the past  years, including a guarantee of a year’s post-diagnostic support, better education and training for staff in health and social care and better standards of care for people with dementia in hospitals.There is still, however, an unacceptable gap between national policy and dementia care and support in our communities. Alzheimer Scotland wants to make sure that people with dementia and their carers can work with local decision makers, helping to influence important decisions about how vital care and support is delivered in their area.We need your help to ensure people with dementia and carers get the best possible standard of care and support, anywhere in Scotland. To find out more visit www.alzscot.org get_involved or call our freephone Dementia Helpline on   .Henry Simmons, chief executive, Alzheimer Scotland.Bed blocking is costing NHS Scotland £ million a year, with one of the main reasons being a delay in care packages for elderly patients.The real cost, in misery and uncertainty, is to the patients who are in the wrong care settings.Despite its promises, the SNP has failed to eradicate delayed discharge.Councillor Alastair Redman, Islay.

title: ardrishaig is anna fedorovas first stop on a fantasy journey
story: Philip Bowden-SmithUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated -days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as  pence per week.Subscribe Nowby Philip Bowden-SmithSaturday September  evening’s recital, the first in the MAAA’s th winter series, was given by the acclaimed -year-old Ukranian pianist, Anna Fedorova.It was obvious from the worldwide plaudits she had received that we were to hear world-class piano playing and we were not disappointed.Anna’s cleverly devised programme centred on five generally well-known works by five dferent composers which all contained reference to ‘fantasy’ in their titles. She explained her fascination with how each portrayed the concept in very dferent ways, from the peaceful portrayal of moonlit nature to expressions of personal  emotion, struggle and grief.The first work Anna played was Scriabin’s second Sonata, Sonata Fantasie. The ‘moonlit’ first movement was exquisite and the execution of the theme and pianissimo accompaniment at the end was stunning: the helter skelter finale was brilliant.Chopin’s Fantasie in F min, which followed, took us into the realms of personal struggle and, with Anna’s innate musicianship, she made cohesive sense of what can appear a somewhat fragmented work.To end the first part of the recital we heard a flawless rendition of Beethoven’s much-loved Moonlight Sonata, and despite the high octane speed of the finale one could hear every single note.After the interval came Mozart’s D min Fantasia. This deceptively easy-looking short piece, executed perfectly by Anna, demonstrated how dficult it is to play his music where every note and phrase requires minute attention.To conclude her recital, Anna chose Schumann’s great Fantasie in C. This work, while dedicated to Franz Liszt is, in the first movement at least, more an outpouring of his frustration at being denied the hand of his beloved Clara with all its sudden changes in mood. The very technically demanding second movement – a march – is more of a dedication to Liszt and was a thrilling listen. The final slow transcendental movement, which could well have been inspired by the opening movement of Beethoven’s Moonlight Sonata, took us into a world of ethereal tranquility.After much applause Anna gave us Rachmaninov’s Prelude in G# min. Op. No. as a fitting encore.After this ‘fantasy’ journey one could only join with those who have been so impressed by the depth and power of Anna’s musicianship. Her ability to squeeze the last drop of emotion from every phrase was very special and a privilege to experience. Finally, to walk out into the clear night air and see the moonlight reflected off the sea like shards of silver seemed an apt end to an evening of fantasy.PIC:Pianist prodigy, Anna Feorova.
